title: R46117
content: The TEACH Grant program provides grants to students pursuing teaching careers. Recipients must teach for four years in a high-need field at a qualifying school. Failure to fulfill this obligation results in the grant converting to a loan. Over 300,000 grants totaling nearly $938 million have been disbursed since 2008. The program has faced challenges in recent years. The TEACH Grant program faces challenges with loan conversions when recipients fail to submit paperwork on time, leading to a high expected failure rate. The Department of Education is working to address administrative issues, but concerns remain about the program's efficacy and design. Congressional attention may focus on these issues. The TEACH Grant program faces challenges with loan conversions due to paperwork delays, leading to a high failure rate. Lawmakers may need to address issues related to program implementation, teacher preparation program quality, and the definition of a "highly qualified teacher." Other proposed changes since the program's authorization should also be considered. The TEACH Grant program, authorized in 2007, aims to address the shortage of qualified teachers in public schools. Concerns about the demand for high-quality teachers in low-income schools led to its creation. Bills introduced in 2005 highlighted the need for 2 million new teachers over the next decade. The TEACH Grant program, established in 2007, aims to attract high-achieving individuals into teaching to meet the demand in low-income schools. It addresses concerns about teacher shortages driven by retirements and minimum standards set by the No Child Left Behind Act. The program provides financial incentives to help subsidize college costs for individuals entering the teaching profession. The TEACH Grant program aims to attract high-achieving individuals into teaching by providing financial incentives to offset college costs. It distinguishes between upfront grants for students starting studies and assistance for teachers already in the field. The program focuses on incentivizing individuals to teach in schools and subjects that struggle to attract staff, particularly in low-income areas. Recipients are expected to obtain teaching certification in a STEM subject and serve as a teacher in a high-need LEA for at least two years for each year of scholarship receipt. Grants convert to a loan if recipients do not teach in a qualifying school, fail to provide documentation, or complete the required service within eight years. The TEACH Grants have an eight-year period for recipients to complete their teaching service obligation. If recipients stop their eligible program before completion, the grant converts to a loan unless they qualify for a suspension. The eight-year period starts after program completion, but recipients can request a suspension for various reasons, like enrolling in another TEACH Grant-eligible program or a state-required certification program. TEACH Grants have an eight-year period for recipients to fulfill their teaching service obligation. Service obligations can be canceled in case of death or total disability. Recipients may also be discharged from part or all of their obligation if called to military duty for more than three years. Multiple TEACH Grants for different programs of study are possible. TEACH Grants recipients must complete four years of teaching service for each program of study. Creditable teaching service, approved suspensions, and service discharge due to military duty may apply to multiple service obligations. To be eligible for a TEACH Grant, an institution must meet financial responsibility standards, offer a high-quality teacher preparation program accredited by an ED-recognized agency or approved by a state, provide at least 10 weeks of pre-service clinical experience, and offer pedagogical coursework and support services to teachers. The institution must offer services to teachers, such as providing information on effective teaching skills and strategies, supervision practices, and mentoring. It should also provide a program of study acceptable for a bachelor's teacher preparation degree or a degree in a high-need field at another TEACH Grant-eligible institution. Additionally, it should offer a bachelor's degree that prepares students to teach in a high-need field and have an agreement with another institution offering teacher preparation programs. The program experienced a surge in awards in recent years, with sequestration scheduled to continue through FY2029. In recent years, analyses of the TEACH Grant program have revealed low benefit take-up rates and high grant-to-loan conversion rates. The Government Accountability Office estimated that only 19% of eligible individuals received grants in 2013-2014. An American Institutes for Research study found that 63% of recipients had their grants converted to loans by July 2016. The Department of Education estimates that 66% of students will fail to complete their service obligation, leading to grant conversion to loans.
